__data__.text: The geology of central southern Turkey and northwestern Syria is shaped by the interaction of the African, Arabian, and Anatolian tectonic plates. The Dead Sea Transform (DST) and the East Anatolian Fault (EAF) are major left-lateral strike-slip fault zones that accommodate the relative movement of these plates. The DST, which separates the African and Arabian plates, meets the EAF at the Marash Triple Junction and continues westward, forming the boundary between the African and Anatolian plates. The EAF is subdivided into several segments, including the Karlıova, Ilıca, Palu, Pütürge, Erkenek, Pazarcık, and Amanos segments, as well as a northern strand that includes the Sürgü, Çardak, Savrun, Çokak, Toprakkale, Yumurtalık, Karataş, Yakapınar, and Düziçi–İskenderun segments. The EAF has produced several large or damaging earthquakes in the past few hundred years. The DST is divided into several segments in Turkey and Syria, and has also generated significant earthquakes. Certain sections of the EAF and DST have a high potential for future earthquakes due to stress accumulation.

The geology of central southern Turkey and northwestern Syria is influenced by the interaction of the African, Arabian, and Anatolian tectonic plates, with the Dead Sea Transform (DST) and the East Anatolian Fault (EAF) as major fault zones. The EAF, which is divided into several segments, has a history of generating significant earthquakes. A research paper identified two sections of the EAF with high potential for future earthquakes, one in Elazığ and Bingöl, and another in Kahramanmaraş, which has a 103 km seismic gap and could produce a magnitude 7.3 earthquake. The DST has also experienced large earthquakes, including a recent Mw 7.8 and Mw 7.7 earthquake in 2023, which are the largest in Turkey in over 2,000 years. These earthquakes triggered numerous aftershocks, with over 30,000 recorded by May 2023. The Pazarcık and Amanos segments of the EAF have recurrence intervals of 237-772 years and 414-917 years, respectively, for M 7.0-7.4 earthquakes.

The Mw 7.8 and Mw 7.7 earthquakes in Turkey resulted in numerous aftershocks, with the USGS and the Turkish Disaster and Emergency Management Presidency recording over 170 and 120 aftershocks, respectively. The aftershocks were distributed along the East Anatolian Fault (EAF) and the Çardak Fault, with the Mw 7.7 earthquake triggering its own aftershock sequence. The USGS produced source models for both earthquakes, revealing multiple fault segments with varying lengths, widths, strikes, and dips. The Mw 7.8 earthquake produced a maximum slip of 11.2 m (37 ft), while the Mw 7.7 earthquake had a maximum displacement of 11.4 m (37 ft). The Mw 6.4 aftershock that struck Antakya had a rupture area of 25 km (16 mi) × 25 km (16 mi) and produced a peak slip of 0.93 m (3 ft 1 in) at 8.3 km (5.2 mi) depth. Preliminary analysis suggests that the stress changes caused by the M7.8 earthquake may have triggered rupture on the Çardak–Sürgü Fault, assuming it was already close to failure.

The Mw 7.8 and Mw 7.7 earthquakes in Turkey caused numerous aftershocks, extending slip to varying distances on different fault segments. The Mw 6.4 aftershock in Antakya had a rupture area of 25 km x 25 km and a peak slip of 0.93 m at 8.3 km depth. Preliminary analysis suggests that stress changes from the M7.8 earthquake may have triggered rupture on the Çardak–Sürgü Fault, and the Hatay Fault's stress increased by 1 bar following the earthquakes.

The M7.8 earthquake initiated on the Narlı Fault, part of the Dead Sea Transform, and ruptured northwards until it reached the Pazarcık segment of the East Anatolian Fault (EAF). Ruptures then continued bilaterally along this segment, resulting in a Mw 7.0 earthquake that lasted for 20 seconds. The rupture propagated at supershear velocity after traveling about 19.5 km away from the epicenter along the Narlı Fault. The second M>7 earthquake initiated on the Çardak–Sürgü Fault Zone, part of the northern strand of the EAF, and propagated bilaterally along the Çardak segment before continuing eastwards onto the Sürgü segment. The total rupture length was estimated at 160 km.

Surface ruptures associated with the M7.8 and M7.7 earthquakes have been mapped using satellite imagery and ground observations, revealing two separate zones of surface rupture.

The total rupture length of the earthquakes in Turkey was estimated to be 160 km (99 mi), with the westward-propagating rupture occurring at supershear velocity and the eastward-propagating rupture occurring at subshear velocity. The Mw 6.4 aftershock on February 20 occurred along the Hatay Fault with normal faulting. Surface ruptures, up to 7.3 m (24 ft) displacement, were observed and mapped using satellite imagery and ground observations, extending from north of Antakya, Hatay Province towards Pazarcık, Kahramanmaraş Province and Gölbaşı, Adıyaman Province. Ground acceleration values in some areas near the fault rupture exceeded 1 g, with a maximum recorded pga of 2.212 g in Pazarcık. The maximum Mercalli intensity of the mainshock was estimated to have reached MMI XI-XII (Extreme) in Antakya and near the epicenter, and MMI X (Extreme) in other areas.

The earthquakes in Turkey resulted in extensive damage and loss of life, with a total rupture length of 160 km (99 mi). The aftershock on February 20, with a magnitude of 6.4, occurred along the Hatay Fault with normal faulting. Ground acceleration values exceeded 1 g in some areas, and maximum recorded pga was 2.212 g in Pazarcık. The maximum Mercalli intensity (MMI) reached XI-XII (Extreme) near the epicenter and in Antakya, X (Extreme) in Kahramanmaraş and other areas, and lower intensities in other provinces. Liquefaction and lateral spreading were observed in several areas, including the Amik Valley, Orontes River plain, and Lake Gölbaşı, causing damage and flooding in İskenderun. A tsunami was recorded in the Mediterranean Sea, with small waves along the southern Turkish coast. In Turkey, there were 50,783 deaths, 297 missing, and 107,204 injured. At least 15.73 million people and 4 million buildings were affected, with 345,000 apartments destroyed. The Turkish government conducted damage inspections, revealing 164,000 buildings were destroyed or severely damaged, and over 2.7 million people were made homeless. Recovery efforts uncovered body parts in the rubble. In Adana and Malatya, many buildings collapsed or were damaged, with significant casualties and destruction of infrastructure.

The earthquakes in Turkey caused widespread destruction, including collapsed and damaged buildings in Adana, Malatya, and various districts in Hatay Province. Many historical sites and infrastructure were severely affected. In İskenderun, a large fire at the port disrupted its operations. Recovery efforts uncovered body parts in the rubble, and a significant number of deaths and injuries were reported in several cities. The disaster affected millions of people, destroyed numerous buildings, and caused the collapse of some local facilities. The port fire in İskenderun added to the challenges in the recovery process.

The earthquakes in Turkey resulted in significant damage in various cities, including the collapse of over 300 buildings in Reyhanlı, 187 in Arsuz, 131 in Kumlu, and 58 in Payas. İskenderun was particularly affected, with a large fire at the port causing operation disruptions, 534 building collapses, and extensive damage to over 4,600 buildings. Flooding and the destruction of the Cathedral of the Annunciation were also reported in İskenderun. Other districts, such as Erzin, Samandağ, Hassa, Altınözü, Yayladağı, Belen, and Dörtyol, experienced building collapses and severe damage. Mass burials took place in Kahramanmaraş, and up to 10% of Adıyaman's population perished, with over 20,000 buildings destroyed in Adıyaman Province. Severe damage was reported in various neighborhoods and villages across the affected areas.

The earthquakes caused extensive damage in various cities of Turkey, particularly in Adıyaman where four neighborhoods were destroyed, including many buildings along Atatürk Boulevard and the city hall. The province's largest hotel, Isias Hotel, also collapsed, killing 65 people. Up to 10% of the city's population perished. Other districts, such as Gölbaşı, experienced significant destruction, with 71% of its infrastructure damaged or destroyed. In Diyarbakir Province, 8,086 buildings were damaged, and Diyarbakır Fortress, a UNESCO World Heritage Site, was partly destroyed. In Syria, at least 8,476 people died and over 14,500 were injured, with many children and women among the casualties. Various public figures, including a member of the Turkish parliament, a goalkeeper, a former national handball player, and a community leader, also perished in the disaster.

The earthquake resulted in the death of three Turkish soldiers during rescue operations and caused significant damage in Syria, where at least 8,476 people died and over 14,500 were injured. The death toll included 2,153 children and 1,524 women. Many public figures in Turkey and civilians in Syria perished in the disaster. Rescue efforts were hindered by the lack of rescue teams, and hundreds were killed in towns such as Jindires, Atarib, and Jableh. The earthquake also caused damage to various archaeological sites and infrastructure in Syria. In rebel-held areas, the earthquake struck as they were preparing for a blizzard and experiencing a cholera outbreak. At least 444 people died in Aleppo, and various archaeological sites across the city were extensively damaged. The disaster left an estimated 5.37 million people homeless in Syria, and thousands of buildings had partially or fully collapsed in the country. The Associated Press reported that the Afrin Dam had cracked and burst, flooding a nearby village and displacing hundreds of families. The Syrian American Medical Society reported that emergency rooms were overwhelmed with injured people. The earthquake also caused cracks in the outer façade of the Aleppo National Museum and affected about 20,000 homes in Aleppo, leaving 70,000 people homeless. In Rajo, the doors and walls of a prison facility were cracked.

The earthquake resulted in a significant loss of life and property in both Turkey and Syria. In Syria, over 8,400 people died, including 2,153 children and 1,524 women, and at least 444 people died in Aleppo. Many buildings collapsed, leaving an estimated 5.37 million people homeless. The disaster also affected various archaeological sites and infrastructure. In rebel-held areas, the earthquake struck as they were preparing for a blizzard and experiencing a cholera outbreak. The earthquake caused additional damage to already war-torn Syria, affecting various historical sites. In addition, at least 6,600 Syrians residing in Turkey were killed. The disaster also affected other countries, including Lebanon, Israel, Cyprus, Iraq, Egypt, and Russia, causing damage to buildings and infrastructure. Aftershocks, including a Mww 6.3 aftershock in Antakya, caused further damage and loss of life. Footballer Nader Joukhadar and his son were among those killed in Jableh when their home collapsed. In Aleppo, at least 444 people died, including 163 children, and about 20,000 homes were affected, leaving 70,000 people homeless. The Syrian American Medical Society reported that emergency rooms were overwhelmed with injured people. The Associated Press reported that the Afrin Dam had cracked and burst, flooding a nearby village and displacing hundreds of families. The Citadel of Aleppo, Margat, Krak des Chevaliers castle, Sahyun Castle, and the minaret of the Grand Mosque in Kobanî were all affected by the earthquake. In Jindires, over 1,100 people were killed and at least 250 buildings were razed. In Rajo, the doors and walls of a prison facility were cracked, allowing 20 prisoners, believed to be Islamic State (ISIS) members, to escape. In Damascus, many people fled from their homes onto the streets. In the northern parts of the city, many buildings were cracked. In Lebanon, buildings shook for up to 40 seconds, causing residents to flee their homes and stay in the streets or drive in their vehicles. The earthquake damaged 16,200 buildings across the country, including

The earthquake and aftershocks caused significant damage and loss of life in both Turkey and Syria, with over 15,000 reported deaths and millions displaced. The disaster also affected various archaeological sites and infrastructure in the region. Shaking was felt in several other countries, including Egypt, Lebanon, and Iraq, causing damage to buildings and infrastructure. The disaster exacerbated existing humanitarian crises in rebel-held areas of Syria. The economic impact of the earthquake in Turkey includes a significant drop in the value of the Turkish lira, a fall in the country's stock market, and an estimated $84.1 billion in damages. The Turkish government has estimated the total damage cost at $103.6 billion. The disaster's impact on Syria's war-torn infrastructure and economy is not yet fully known. Experts predict that the death toll may exceed 100,000, and up to 26 million people may have been affected.

Note: The numbers and statistics mentioned in the summary are approximate and may vary based on different sources.

The earthquake and aftershocks in Turkey and Syria resulted in significant damage and loss of life, as well as affecting archaeological sites and infrastructure in the region. The disaster also had a major economic impact, causing a drop in the Turkish stock market and an estimated $84.1 billion in damages in Turkey alone. The Turkish government has estimated the total damage cost at $103.6 billion, while experts predict that the death toll in Syria may exceed 100,000. In the immediate aftermath, thousands were trapped under rubble and many were left homeless in freezing temperatures. The Turkish government and various humanitarian institutions have launched emergency appeals to help the victims. The Disaster and Emergency Management Authority opened an invitation for citizen volunteers to help with rescue efforts. Search and rescue teams were immediately dispatched to the affected area and officials urged residents to avoid entering damaged buildings. The volume of building debris in Turkey is estimated to be greater than any recent natural disaster, and the reconstruction cost in Syria is estimated at $7.9 billion. The disaster also exacerbated existing humanitarian crises in rebel-held areas of Syria. The economic impact of the earthquake in Turkey includes a significant drop in the value of the Turkish lira and a fall in the country's stock market. The disaster's impact on Syria's war-torn infrastructure and economy is not yet fully known. The United Nations Development Programme estimated that between 116 million and 210 million tons of debris must be cleared in Turkey.

In the aftermath of the earthquake and aftershocks in Turkey and Syria, thousands of volunteers arrived at Istanbul Airport to assist in rescue efforts. Turkish Airlines and Pegasus Airlines flew a significant number of volunteers and evacuees to and from the affected areas. The Turkish government declared a state of emergency in the 10 affected provinces and appealed for international aid. Emergency services were activated, and over 53,000 Turkish emergency workers were deployed to the affected regions. Poor weather conditions and damaged infrastructure posed challenges to rescue efforts. On February 19, search and rescue operations were largely discontinued, with a focus on 40 remaining buildings in Kahramanmaraş and Hatay provinces. Various charity and volunteer campaigns, as well as government assistance, were initiated to support those affected by the disaster.

Following the earthquake, several TV and radio channels organized the Türkiye Beats with One Heart Campaign, raising $6.1 billion, with the Central Bank of the Republic of Turkey being the largest donor. The government promised to compensate those who lost their homes, providing relocation assistance and rent support. President Erdoğan pledged to rebuild destroyed homes within a year and established temporary accommodations. Tax obligations in the affected region were postponed until July 2023. Over 1.9 million people were rehoused in various facilities, and 387,000 tents were set up. The government announced plans to construct 270,000 homes in the affected provinces. There were incidents involving attacks, prison riots, and the suspension of rescue operations due to security concerns. A natural gas explosion and a fire resulted in casualties among earthquake survivors. The PKK declared a ceasefire and urged all groups to stop military actions to focus on recovery efforts.

After the earthquake, there were incidents affecting the rescue efforts, such as prisoners demanding to see their families, German and Austrian rescuers temporarily suspending operations due to security concerns, and the Israeli search-and-rescue group leaving Turkey due to a specific threat. There were also several accidents, including a fire in a temporary home, a gas explosion, a bus collision, and a tornado at a camp for earthquake survivors, resulting in casualties and injuries. Floods in Adıyaman and Şanlıurfa caused further damage and loss of life. The government had planned to hold elections in May 2023, but there were discussions about postponing them due to the earthquake, with some politicians opposing the idea on constitutional grounds. Education and sports were also affected, with universities suspending education and sports leagues being postponed in honor of the victims.

The presidential election in Turkey went into a run-off for the first time, and education and sports were significantly impacted by the earthquake. Universities in the affected provinces suspended education indefinitely, and student hostels were used to house those affected. Schools across the country were closed for two weeks, with students in the affected provinces being transferred to other provinces. Sports leagues, including Süper Lig, were suspended, and several clubs from affected regions withdrew from competition. National championships were also suspended until further notice. The earthquake resulted in several fatalities among sports teams, including the entire high school volleyball team of Türk Maarif Koleji and players from Iran's national paralympic football team. Fans protested the Turkish government during football games, demanding its resignation. In Syria, President Bashar al-Assad organized a rescue plan for the affected regions, and the Syrian government appealed to international organizations for aid, requesting to be responsible for aid distribution in all areas of the country. However, damaged roads and logistical issues prevented the mobilization of international aid across the border from Turkey, and critically injured patients were unable to enter Turkey for medical attention.

Syria requested aid from the European Union and asked to oversee distribution in rebel-held areas. The UK and US plan to deliver aid through their respective partners, while the UN sent medical convoys to affected regions. Local charities, including Saed Initiative and al-Bir and al-Ihsan, have been working at full capacity to provide meals. Over 2,000 White Helmets volunteers have been conducting search and rescue efforts, facing equipment shortages. The US eased sanctions for 180 days to facilitate earthquake relief transactions. Humanitarian aid from Turkey started entering northwestern Syria on 9 February via the Bab al-Hawa Border Crossing.

Following the earthquake, there were calls to lift or suspend sanctions on Syria to aid humanitarian relief efforts. The US temporarily eased sanctions for 180 days, specifically for transactions related to earthquake relief. However, the Syrian government criticized this decision, claiming it was misleading. Humanitarian assistance from various countries and organizations, including the US, Turkey, EU, NATO, and the UN, began entering northwestern Syria via the Bab al-Hawa Border Crossing. Schools in some regions remained closed, and the Syrian government agreed to open two additional border crossings. President al-Assad met with UN relief chief Martin Griffiths to discuss post-earthquake recovery and aid. The World Bank pledged US$1.78 billion in aid for Turkey's relief and recovery process. Criticism of the Turkish government emerged on social media, alleging a cover-up of the actual death toll and the number of mainshocks.

The World Bank is providing immediate assistance for the earthquake disaster, while criticism against the Turkish government continues to grow due to allegations of downplaying the actual number of mainshocks and the death toll. The government is also accused of inadequately enforcing building codes, leading to the collapse of many buildings, including newly constructed ones. Satellite image analysis and engineers' warnings support these allegations. Protests have erupted in affected areas, with locals expressing anger towards the government and officials. The opposition leader has criticized the government for the disaster's scale and has urged mayors to continue aid efforts despite potential bureaucratic obstacles.

The Turkish government faces criticism for its handling of the 2020 Izmir earthquake, with allegations of downplaying the disaster's scale, profiting from a zoning amnesty law, and inadequate distribution of aid. Opposition leader Kemal Kılıçdaroğlu accuses the government of worsening the disaster's impact and calls for continued aid provision despite potential obstacles. Delays in AFAD's response, merging of relief agencies, and a centralized decision-making process are also criticized. The slow government response in Samandağ led residents to dig through rubble for victims. The government blocked Twitter access, causing public anger and concerns about aid organization and information sharing.

The opposition criticizes a measure as unnecessary, citing existing disaster area declarations. Residents in Samandağ had to search for victims themselves due to slow government aid. The government blocks Twitter, causing public anger and concerns about aid coordination and information sharing. Fines and suspensions are issued to media outlets for their earthquake coverage. Authorities arrest individuals for social media posts and looting, with allegations of torture and discrimination against Syrians. A judicial investigation is initiated to hold accountable those responsible for building collapses. Journalists are detained and harassed for their earthquake reporting. Arrests are made for cutting down columns and negligent inspections, and individuals are investigated for involvement in building collapses.

The opposition criticizes a measure as unnecessary due to existing disaster declarations, while residents in Samandağ had to search for victims themselves due to slow government aid. The government's blocking of Twitter causes public anger and concerns about aid coordination and information sharing. Media outlets face fines and suspensions for earthquake coverage, and individuals are arrested for social media posts, looting, and "spreading misinformation." Arrests are made for cutting down columns, negligent inspections, and involvement in building collapses. Some buildings that collapsed were built after 2000, despite improved regulations and materials following the 1999 earthquake. Corruption in the construction sector is highlighted as a potential issue. Seven days of national mourning are declared in Turkey, Northern Cyprus, Bangladesh, and Kosovo, while criticism of aid distribution arises from the Syrian government, opposition, and international community. The UN has been criticized for focusing aid on regime-held areas, and the SSG-aligned Tahrir al-Sham rebel militia commander calls for more proactive international relief efforts. The UN urges the Security Council to permit aid flows into Northwestern Syria, and the US calls for an emergency UN Security Council meeting to increase humanitarian assistance.

The UN Secretary-General, António Guterres, urged the Security Council to allow immediate aid deliveries into northwestern Syria. The US called for an emergency UN meeting and the opening of more border crossings for UN aid. Some aid has entered through Bab Al-Hawa, but the UN lacks heavy equipment and search and rescue teams. Syrian Civil Defence chief, Raed al-Saleh, criticized the UN for its delayed response. Extreme cold and water shortages in Turkey and Syria pose health risks, including hypothermia and waterborne diseases. Turkey's Health Minister reported increased infection cases, while a Kahramanmaraş shelter clinic treated thousands of patients. Health authorities in Turkey are working to prevent disease outbreaks among earthquake survivors, with support from the World Health Organization.
